title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.10 Part 1 | 13-12-2021
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: This particular verse is a very famous verse. It's called the Atmarama verse.
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and introduces the Atmarama verse (SB 1.7.10) as a central topic, highlighting its significance and the transcendental qualities of the Lord.

segments.key_quote: So combining the different meanings, there are so many meanings of the verse that can be derived.
segments.summary: This segment explains the meaning of the Atmarama verse, emphasizing Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu's 61 different interpretations and Srila Prabhupada's elaborate purport, focusing on the multiple meanings of key terms within the verse.

segments.key_quote: Lord Chaitanya says, according to the Vishwa Prakasha, Sanskrit dictionary, there are seven synonyms for the word Atmarama.
segments.summary: The speaker delves into the various meanings of the words 'Atmarama,' 'Munayaha,' and 'Nirgrantha,' drawing from Sanskrit dictionaries and scriptures to provide a comprehensive understanding of these terms.

segments.key_quote: So this word urukrama specifically indicates the lord's incarnation as Vamana.
segments.summary: The lecture continues by defining 'Urukrama' and relating it to Lord Vishnu's incarnation as Vamana, highlighting the Lord's glorious activities and potencies in creating both the spiritual and material worlds.

segments.key_quote: Krishna is both attractive and very pleasing he is the most sublime abode of transcendental bliss
segments.summary: The speaker explains 'Itthambhoota Guna' as transcendental bliss, contrasting it with Brahmananda and emphasizing the supreme attractiveness and pleasure derived from realizing and serving Lord Krishna through devotional service (bhakti).
